The Candrakiraṇa

Digital Edition of Candrakiraṇa

edited by Zakariya Pamuji Aminullah

Current Version: , 2022-06-27Z
Still in progress – do not quote without permission.
  • Witnesses
  • Metadata

List of Witnesses

  • J1: Perpustakaan Nasional Republik Indonesia, Jakarta, Lontar, L631
    • J2: Perpustakaan Nasional Republik Indonesia, Jakarta, Lontar, L298
      • J3: Perpustakaan Nasional Republik Indonesia, Jakarta, Lontar, L241
        • B1: Pusat Dokumentasi Dinas Kebudayaan Provinsi Bali, Bali, Lontar, K/I/2/DOKBUD
          • Content:
            • Aji Canda
          • Colophon:
          • B2: Leiden University, Leiden, Leiden University Libraries, Or 11.185
            • Content:
              • Aji Canda
            • Colophon:

            Metadata of the Edition

            • Title: The Candrakiraṇa. Digital Edition of Candrakiraṇa
            • Text Identifier: DHARMA_CritEdCandrakirana
            • Edited by Zakariya Pamuji Aminullah
            • Copyright © 2019-2025 by Zakariya Pamuji Aminullah.

            This project has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

            invocation

            J2:1rB1:1vB2:1v (1)om̐ avighnam astu

            1.

            Introduction

            (2)kiraṇo (3)vyaktiś (4)candrāgneḥ, (5)dvijānāṁ kavir (6)uttamaḥ.

            1.1

            nahan byakta pinakaśarīra bhaṭāra, (7)milvājanmāgave bhuvana, sira (8)tāṣṭatanu ṅaranira, sira (9)tāṣṭadeśomidәr pinakavәṅku, sira (10)ta huripnikaṅ rāt, sira dumadyakәn vr̥ddhiniṅ janma kabeh, prāṇaprāṇī sarva hurip, ikanaṅ urip lavan avak, śarīra pamisanya riṅ (11)sādhārādheya, gumavay ikaṅ sarva dadi, sira sinaṅguh pūrvaniṅ janma.

            Translation

            No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdCandrakirana

            1.2

            umijil taṅ aṣṭatanu riṅ rat, nara, (12)paśu, mr̥ga, janma, (13)sthāvara, pakṣi, sarīsr̥pa, (14)mīna, (15)prabhavaniṅ ādhārādheya

            Parallels
              nara, paśu, mr̥ga, janma, sthāvara, pakṣi, sarīsr̥pa, mīna
            • BrP73.14 mānuṣa paśu mr̥ga sarīsr̥pa pakṣi sthāvara.
            Translation

            No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdCandrakirana

            1.3

            prabhu rāma r̥ṣi, tiga sira, pramāṇa riṅ rat, (16)pakə̄niṅ bhuvana, tuvi sira (17)tunduk apeśīki, guruniṅ janma kabeh, (18)lvirnira irikaṅ (19)chandanira, ṅkāna sira tika siddhaguru, sira (20)tāṣṭagaṇa (21)guṇanira gumavayB2:2r ikaṅ varta sәk lumrā.

            Translation

            No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdCandrakirana

            2.

            Origin of the kakavin meters

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            ikaṅ (22)akṣaropamāvak, ika ta guru ṅaranya, (23)yeki ta vinastu hurip, ya sinaṅguh guru laghu. 1

            ya (24)pinakamūla chanda, (25)avaknikaṅ guru laghu, lavan hurip (26)masaṅyoga, umijil tikaṅ (27)trigaṇa. 2

            adәgnikaṅ guru laghu, aniga-nigeṅ (28)sagaṇa, (29)yekāṣṭagaṇa ṅaranya, (30)sama tāvyāpāre vr̥tta. 3

            [line 1] (31)mvaṅ laku śloka nihan len.

            3.

            Long syllabes

            Śārdūlavikrīḍita:  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            sakveh saṅ (32)sujanātiharṣa (33)irikaṅ chandā nihan (34)kavruhi, yan maJ2:1vhyun vruha rūpaniṅ (35)laghu lavan tekā sinaṅguh guru, (36)bhedanyaṅ guru (37)lāghu yeṅәtakәna mvaṅ (38)huṅgvaniṅ hakṣara, sakvehniṅ guru (39)yeriṅәn (40)hila-hilekā yan salah (41)kasthānan. 1

            (42)bhyaktāniṅ guru sarva (43)dīrgha taruṅā saṅyogapārānәṅәn, (44)lāvan karṇa visarja (45)kāni śurahan (46)svārāṅ vatәk (47)vyañjana, e ai (48)nāhan (49)anuṅ (50)kayatnakәna len (51)o au (52)vәkasniṅ guru, vus meṅәt pva (53)kiterikā niyata yan (54)sotanta (55)dadyā vacan. 2

            lvirniṅ (56)hakṣara gantuṅәn (57)mapakәneṅ (58)vaktā mvaṅ aṅgantuṅa, (59)saṅyogāpara (60)sūkṣma (61)lakṣmaṇa śivāgni kleśa (62)lakṣmī kunaṅ, (63)ndan (64)glāna sthula (65)nagna vighna (66)mamәvә̄ nirvighna (67)māra sthiti, svapna sneha rikaṅ (68)dvitīya kahaḍaṅ riṅ (69)dlāha yan (70)pāphala. 3

            (71)vahniṅ tīkṣṇa murub riṅ (72)adri ya katon raśminya (73)sāteja ya, (74)masnāna pva kiteṅ (75)nadī (76)masәh ikaṅ saśleṣma (77)kumlābakәn, riṅ (78)smāroṅgva sahiṣṇu nora pinaṅan maṅlih (79)mvaṅ aṅgantuṅa, yapvan bheda (80)sakojarojarakәnan maṅke (81)balikniṅ vacan. 4

            Drutavilambita:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (82)gәlana saṅ (83)lagәna n para (84)riṅ sәma, (85)vighәna (86)tikṣəṇa (87)yogi ri tulya ya, (88)divadaśeka (89)tuhunya (90)sanirghәna, (91)masupәna (92)pva (93)vadhū (94)sumәneha ya. 1

            (95)vagәmi yan (96)paḍәman (97)mahəm iṅ (98)hati, tuvi (99)kәleśa (100)vināśa (101)salakṣәmi, (102)sәpinikaṅ brata (103)marganikan kәlәm, kramaniB2:3rṅ akṣara yan (104)jinajār ika. 2

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            (105)lvirniṅ (106)saṁyogaparekī, (107)kakyan kakyan (108)kakvan kakvan, kakran (109)anәṅәn (110)aṅgantuṅ, kayatnakәn (111)tәmәntәmәn. 1

            (112)anta pāda guru yati, kalavan (113)svara kamadhya, (114)dīrghadīrgha (115)vr̥ttavati, (116)tāvat guru (117)prasiddha ya. 2

            dīrgha (118)taruṅa (119)surahan, (120)visarga lavan (121)ajuṅjuṅ, kalavan guru saṁyoga, nahan taṅ sinaṅguh guru. 3

            nihan taṅ svara (122)kamadhya, a (123)ā i ī u ū e (124)o, tan (125)dadi (126)muṅguh riṅ (127)tәṅah, vvītan juga (128)prakr̥tinya. 4

            4.

            Aṣṭagaṇa

            Vaṁśapatrapatita:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            sampun ikaṅ (129)pratekanikanaṅ guru (130)dinәliṅakәn, (131)nyā t ajarәn (132)muvah paduluriṅ guru (133)laghu vuvusәn, (134)kvehnya (135)savarga (136)muṅguh ikanaṅ (137)vacan aniganiga, yeka (138)sinaṅguhan (139)gaṇa ṅaranya sipatiṅ (140)aṅavi. 1

            (141)pūrva nihan (142)makāra ṅaraniṅ guru tiga sagaṇa, (143)lāghu kunaṅ panәṇḍasani luṅguhi yakaragaṇa, yapvan ikaṅ (144)rakāragaṇa (145)lāghu maḍuḍuk (146)i (147)tәṅah, hetunikaṅ sakāragaṇa (148)matvaṅ aguru vәkasan. 2

            (149)vruh pva (150)kitā (151)takāra ṅaraniṅ (152)laghu (153)tәpi kavuri, (154)jātinikaṅ (155)jakāragaṇa maṅkana guru (156)ri (157)tṅah, bhakti jugaṅ (158)bhakāragaṇa (159)riṅ (160)guru sira rumuhun, (161)nākaragāṇa (162)təlv (163)madulur tika ya (164)laghu (165)paḍa. 3

            (166)nya ṅ laghu karva saṅ guru (167)pasəṅgahanika (168)śilalo, (169)śeṣanikaṅ (170)gaṇeki (171)vəkasiṅ guru (172)laghu vinuvus, riṅ (173)haji chanda teki yan (174)avās śiva (175)haji piturun, saṅ r̥ṣi (176)vaṁśapatrapatitā sira (177)tiki (178)manata. 4

            5.

            Ārya Meter

            Jaloddhatagati:  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            nihan (179)gaṇaniṅ (180)ārya (181)yeṅәtakәna, (182)jakāra kalavan (183)bhakāra (184)sakara, catur (185)laghu guru rva yeka ta lima, (186)ləvihnya guru (187)lāghu (188)kānәm (189)ikahən. 1

            lavan hana ta mātra (190)yeṅәtakәna, vilaṅnya (191)rikanaṅ (192)sapāda matәtәg, ikaṅ (193)padika pūrvakā (194)tәlu kunaṅ,B1:5v, (195)gənəp rvavəlas (196)aṅgәpanya (197)tuturən. 2

            kapiṅ rvanikihәn B2:4r (198)pva ya (199)vvaluvәlas, (200)tumut (201)limavәlas (202)padanya (203)vәkasan, tan eva (204)taya (205)tāpa tārya vinuvus, samaṅkana (206)vilaṅni matranikihәn. 3

            mvaṅ (207)uṅgvanikanaṅ (208)jakāra matәtәg, (209)kapiṅ rva maṅənəm (210)dvitīya kasulam, (211)pada (212)rva ya ta (213)hīṅaniṅ vvaṅ (214)amilaṅ, (215)kayatnakәna saṅ vatәk kavivara. 4

            6.

            Words with Retroflex Nasal Ṇa

            Kusumāyudha:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            trigaṇa (216)guṇā gaṇita ya guṇitan, prakaraṇa (217)kīraṇa vaṇa karuṇa, aruṇa (218)darūṇa varuṇa śaraṇa, (219)avaraṇa (220)bhāraṇa (221)ṅ apaṇa (222)ṇa gә̄ṅ. 1

            Praharaṇakalikā:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (223)guṇa (224)kuṇi kuṇa (225)kaṇvi (226)kaṇikaṇika len, (227)ghraṇa (228)ṅ agaṇagaṇa grahaṇa (229)samiraṇa, praṇava (230)vaṇi ya pāṇi ya (231)maṇitaṇitan, (232)ayaṇa (233)karuṇa (234)pāṇa (235)ṇa gәṅa yatika. 2

            Dodhaka:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (236)paṇḍita (237)pāṇḍava pāṇḍura pāṇḍu, (238)piṇḍaṅ apiṇḍa (239)mapaṇḍəṅ (240)amaṇḍi, (241)laṇḍap alaṇḍәp (242)alaṇḍuṅ aləṇḍə̄, gaṇḍi giṇaṇḍi (243)diṇəṇḍa ta (244)ṇāgәṅ. 3

            (245)dhāraṇa (246)vāhaṇa (247)vāraṇa (248)bāṇa, (249)śrāvaṇa varṇa (250)maṇi (251)kṣaṇa karṇa, arṇava (252)kīrṇa (253)suparṇa (254)yaworṇā, (255)cūrṇita pūrṇama ghūrṇita (256)nāgəṅ. 4

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            kagantuṅa deniṅ (257)ṇa gәṅ, (258)ṭa (259)ṭha (260)ḍa (261)ḍha ṇa riṅ ṇa (262)gәṅ,B1:6v ta tha da (263)dha na riṅ na (264)lit, (265)varṇa doh ya (266)sa savarga. 5

            liṅ saṅ (267)kavi (268)vruh iṅ (269)mārga.

            Dodhaka:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            uṅgvanikaṅ (270)na lit (271)āpa pakneki, (272)ndā savanehnya rikaṅ (273)pakənanya, (274)nāta samaṅkana (275)teka na (276)ḍə̄mit, kapva (277)masaṅkhya nihan savanehnya. 6

            7.

            Words with Dental Nasal Na

            Turidagati:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            muni (278)muna (279)nāna samanuṣa, (280)anumana (281)hana (282)naminami, dina dhana (283)nādi (284)nada (285)nana, hani hina (286)tan hana (287)inituṅ. 1

            Name unknown (atijagatī class):  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            praṇata (288)natha (289)prajapātini (290)tanu ya, (291)tanah (292)atunah (293)pinatattva ta (294)tanaya, (295)nita (296)vanitā (297)nininīni tanu tani, mananaB1:7r (298)vanā (299)malinī (300)na lit ikahәn. 2

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            vaneh pakәnaniṅ na lit, nāga (301)punnāganiṅ gunuṅ, nāga nāgendra nāgendrī, nāgari nāga nāginī. 3

            (302)magəni (303)yāgni yāgneya, (304)gagana (305)dinanān (306)dina, ghana (307)vāhana (308)vājinī vāni, (309)nītinitya (310)yanuṅ (311)na lit (312)ika. 4

            dahana jvalana (313)vanā, kāminī vāhinī nini, (314)punah (315)vinā vani vana, vinavan i na lit ika. 5

            (316)saṅkṣepanya yan vuvusәn, yāvat rakva (317)rəṅva pūrva, pa (318)ba mādi kunaṅ pūrva, dadi (319)na lit dadi (320)ṇa gәṅ. 6

            na vyaktanyan (321)huvus kojar, (322)kekadeśanya (323)kokta ya, kocapa teki śa ṣa sa, J2:3v (324)vyaktanya (325)mātra varṇanәnB1:7v. 7

            8.

            Words with Sibilant Śa

            Candravartma:  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            śambhu śaṅkara śarā śaraṇa śaśī, deśa (326)deśika (327)śaśa ṅ (328)śavala (329)kuśa, (330)śvāśucī (331)śuna (332)śirah śiva (333)dr̥śana, śānti śoka (334)paśu (335)śāstra (336)śuna (337)śiśu. 1

            Śikhariṇī:  ⏑  –  –  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            śa (338)mūrdhanyātekaṅ śa (339)kurəb (340)umunīṅ (341)vunvunikahәn, (342)śaśāṅkāśaṅkhā (343)śaṅkara (344)kuśakuśā keśi (345)kuśika, kuśa (346)śrota krośa kraniki katha (347)śabdeṅ (348)śikhariṇī, (349)śikhi ṅ (350)keśīkeśā (351)praśa śakuni (352)keśī (353)kuśakuśa. 2

            śanaih śūnya śreṇi ghrāṇa (354)piśunane (355)śrīyaśa (356)niśā, (357)vināśa (358)mvaṅ (359)māśā daśadiśi (360)śarat (361)śūra raśika, (362)śivā śambhuh (363)śūla (364)triśula (365)muśala (366)śrī vava śiva, (367)śavah (368)vaṅśah (369)veśyah śavari (370)śivirākāśa (371)śucimān. 3

            9.

            Words with Sibilant Ṣa

            Pr̥thvītala:  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            kṣaṇa (372)kṣiṇi kapakṣa lakṣmi (373)viṣayā hahə̄man nidhi, kagantuṅa gumantuṅeṅ (374)ṭa ḍa (375)kunaṅ (376)ṣa pr̥thvītala, (377)prahr̥ṣṭi parituṣṭa roṣa (378)ruṣa (379)poṣya (380)kr̥ṣṇa (381)proṣa, (382)akarṣaṇa (383)ya (384)vr̥ṣṇi (385)vr̥ṣṭa ṣa lumah (386)ṣa pr̥thvītala. 1

            maharṣi (387)mahiṣī (388)mahoṣadha (389)maheṣa meṣā (390)muṣa, (391)rәṣah muṣika (392)puṣya (393)poṣaka puṣa praṣaṣṭā (394)maṣa, (395)ṣaḍaṅguli ṣaḍaṅga (396)bhūṣaṇa (397)subhāṣa durbhāṣita, (398)viṣān (399)uṣadha (400)yauṣadhīṣu (401)viṣama (402)dvipādāsana. 2

            bhaviṣyati (403)hiriṣya (404)harṣaṇa (405)puṣā uṣā (406)tyāṣa len, (407)viṣa ṅ viṣaya (408)yomiśeṣa dadi (409)mānuṣā (410)kāṣaya, (411)nyataṅ kaluṣa kilviṣa ṅ (412)ayuṣa (413)kaṣmalā (414)doṣa ya, (415)nyataṅ mami (416)ṣa yoṅgvaniṅ (417)ṣa (418)marənah (419)riṅ (420)anta ta ya. 3

            Sragdhara:  –  –  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (421)śākāśa mvaṅ (422)sapr̥thvī sadulur ika rәṅәn (423)yekihәn varṇanәn ta, (424)śuśrūṣā (425)śiṣya śikṣā (426)śviśita (427)vәtunikaṅ (428)mośvasā (429)śeṣaśeṣan, (430)śaśvatJ1:5v (431)śīrṣanya (432)śośvi (433)śvaṣinaka (434)śaśi (435)de saṅ (436)vasiṣṭhāJ3:4v (437)śaviṣṭi, (438)maṅkā (439)tekaṅ (440)śaṭhāvor (441)ṣa ta ya tiṅәtiṅәt yeki (442)sākṣāt vәtunya. 4

            10.

            Words with Sibilant Sa

            Basantatilakā:  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (443)māsānikaṅ sa ta nihan vuvusәn padanya, (444)sādhū (445)sadā (446)sata (447)sabhā sisi (448)tāsitāsi, (449)sītā (450)susatya rasa (451)satriya (452)sāri saṅ hyaṅ, (453)svecchā (454)svabhāva ri (455)sarasvati (456)sārisāri. 1

            (457)samvā (458)savah (459)vasumatī (460)vasusena (461)sūnu, (462)mvaṅ (463)ekavāsa (464)hupavāsa (465)vināsavāsa, (466)durbhāṣa (467)duryaśana (468)durvyasana (469)praśasta, (470)byar (471)śāsa (472)sādhu sasivin (473)sapujinsapūjan. 2

            (474)sasvāṅga (475)saṅga sigiB1:9v (476)seṅgita (477)sarga (478)sajja, (479)svaṅgah (480)sәga ṅ (481)siga sugih (482)sigaran (483)sagāsor, sasvarga (484)sāgara (485)sagorava (486)sādhaka (487)syaṅ, (488)rāktosvaniṅ (489)sata (490)sarat (491)pakәnanya sākṣāt. 3

            Citrālaya:  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            sura sapta (492)sarah (493)surasa sira (494)sadā, (495)samasih (496)papasәn (497)savara suta (498)saha, (499)savinaṅ savanәn sakala (500)sakavaśa, (501)praja (502)nāmi (503)sa dantya (504)niti (505)kavivara. 4

            colophon

            iti (506)paruṅguniṅ akṣara.

            12.

            Chanda (Meters)

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            Meter Names According to Number of Syllables

            saṅ hyaṅ jagat (678)tripuruṣa, (679)namo śivāya ta ṅhulun, amvīt (680)umastava kita, amarṇanā (681)vr̥tta vәtun. 1

            guruniṅ jagat kita ya, mūlākṣara guru laghu,B2:9r (682)mātra āryā (683)ya (684)taṅ gaṇa, nāhan ṅaran (685)tataṅ (686)chanda. 2

            kita makarūpa chanda, agave titi mvaṅ śloka, ya ta (687)varṇanәn kavətun, ya (688)pinakasuluhiṅ (689)rāt. 3

            [line 1] lvirniṅ chanda ta ṅaranya, [line 2] kvehiṅ (690)vilaṅniṅ akṣara, [line 3] rikanaṅ (691)pāda sayati, [line 4] (692)pāda ṅaranya sakaṇḍa, [line 5] paB1:13vtaṅ (693)pāda (694)ya (695)saśloka. 4

            mūlanyān (696)keṅәtakəna, akṣara tuṅgal (697)iṅ yati, yeka sinaṅguh antyanta, rvaṅ akṣara (698)atyukta ṅa. 5

            tryakṣara madhyama (699)nāma, pratiṣṭha pataṅ akṣara, (700)śīrṣapratiṣṭha yan lima, (701)nәmaṅ akṣara (702)gāyatrī. 6
            Parallels
              śīrṣapratiṣṭha
            • Vr̥t4 Cf. Vr̥t 3.c: tekaṅ supratiṣṭhan lima.

            (703)uṣṇik (704)ri pituṅ akṣara, vvalu pva ya (705)pādānuṣṭubh, (706)vr̥hati (707)saṅaṅ akṣara, sapuluh pva si (708)pakṣatī. 7
            Parallels
              pakṣatī
            • Vr̥t4 Cf. Vr̥t 4.c: yan sapuluh si paṅkti.

            (709)sasambaha (710)pva (711)savәlas,J2:6r rvavәlas pva (712)ya (713)jagatī, (714)atijagatī (715)tigavlas, (716)śakvarī (717)ya (718)padblas ika. 8
            Parallels
              sasambaha
            • Vr̥t4 Cf. Vr̥t 4c: savəlas triṣṭāpa nāmeriya.

            (719)atiśakvarī (720)limavlas, aṣṭi (721)nәmbәlas (722)ikahәn, (723)atyaṣṭi nahan (724)pituvlas, (725)dhr̥ti (726)yapvan (727)vvaluvәlas. 9

            (728)atidhr̥ti (729)saṅavəlas, rvaṅpuluh (730)ya (731)anukr̥ti (732)kr̥ti, prakr̥ti ya ta salikur, rvalikur ikaṅ ākr̥ti. 10

            (733)tәlulikur (734)iṅ (735)vikr̥ti, padlikur sunāmakr̥ti, (736)abhikr̥ti limalikur, (737)hana (738)utkr̥ti ṅ nәmlikur.(739) 11
            Parallels
              sunāmakr̥ti
            • Vr̥t6 Cf. Vr̥t 6c: yan padlikur saṅskr̥ti.

            12.5

            nihan vartanya:

            Translation

            No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdCandrakirana


            Illustration of Meters on Stanzas

            Nanda:  ⏓ 

            om̐, na, ndā, stu. 1
            Parallels
              ndā
            • Vr̥t Cf. Vr̥t 9.1–4: a, da, nda, yaṅ.

            Bhadra:  –  ⏓ 

            sambah, kvāgəṅ, (814)riṅ hyaṅ, bhadra. 2
            Parallels
              bhadra
            • Vr̥t10.1-4 Cf. Vr̥t 10.1-4: devī, gorī, bhadrā, saśrī.

            Bhadroti:  –  –  ⏓ 

            taṇḍaB1:16rsku, (815)jñānaṅku, (816)bhaktyāgәṅ, (818)bhadroti.(817) 3
            Parallels
              bhadroti
            • Vr̥t11.3-4 Cf. Vr̥t 11.3-4: bāṇī śrī, nārī hyaṅ. The name of this meter in CK is bhadroti, while in Vr̥t is nārī.

            Vanamr̥gī:  –  –  –  ⏓ 

            səkar asәp, (819)paḍanikiṅ, (820)vacavacan, (821)vanamr̥gī. 4
            Parallels
              vanamr̥gī
            • Vr̥t12.3-4 Cf. Vr̥t 12.3-4: cinaru riṅ, vanamṛgī.

            Vijayanti:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (822)saṅ hyaṅ (823)akāśa, (824)bhūh (825)kiraṇendu, (826)agni marut vvai, (827)aum̐ vijayanti. 5
            Parallels
              vijayanti
            • Cf. Vr̥t 13.3-4: mvaṅ stutini ṅvaṅ, om̐ aum vijayanti.

            Tanumadhya:  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (828)sakveh ta vatәk hyaṅ, (829)muṅgv iṅ (830)navadeśa, tonton (831)praṇataṅku, muṅgv iṅ tanumadhya. 6

            (832)liṇḍūmara saṅ hyaṅ, ogah kṣiti molah, (833)keṅgəkJ1:9v (834)vavataṅnya, (835)kanyā tanumadhya. [6] 7
            Parallels
              tanumadhya
            • Cf. Vr̥t 14.4: tanyā tanumadhyā.

            Kusumitagandha:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (836)sahananikiṅ rat, nara taruB2:11r (837)sattva, paḍa ta (838)pinūjeṅ, (839)kusumitagandha. [7] 8
            Parallels
              kusumitagandha
            • Cf. Vr̥t 15.3-4:ṅuni-uni sakveh, kusumitajanma. It is clear that both CK and Vr̥t show the same pattern of this meter as ⏑⏑⏑|⏑–⏓, but Zoetmulder in Kalangwan (p. 451) incorrectly describe the pattern meter as ⏑⏑⏑|⏑⏓.

            Madhukaralalita:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            mata mulat (840)ahəniṅ, damar (841)upamanika, vuvus amanis arūm, madhukaralalita. [8] 9
            Parallels
              madhukaralalita
            • Cf. Vr̥t 16.3-4: pahi mara kalavan, madhukaralalita

            Madalekha:  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (842)sakvehnya ṅ vatu kambaṅ, (843)yeky ānuṅ (844)pamujāṅku, (845)kleśālvāṅa phalanya, naṣṭāniṅ (846)madalekha. [9] 10
            Parallels
              madalekha
            • Cf. Vr̥t 17.4: ronya lvir madaleka.

            Kumāralalita:  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (847)tlas ta (848)ṅhulun (849)amūjā, niroga (850)huna vighna, (851)phalaṅkv (852)anuku (853)śāla, (854)kumāralalitātvaṅ. [10] 11
            Parallels
              kumāralalita
            • Cf. Vr̥t 18.3-4 maṅgih yan cacadən ṅvaṅ kumāralalitāsvi.

            Vatāpathyā:

            (855)nahan (856)sambahkva riṅ deva, (857)karūhun (858)riṅ (859)munīvāra, (860)amītāmarṇanājñāna, (861)vatāpathyātəhər (862)vtunya. [11] 12
            Parallels
              vatāpathya
            • Cf. Vr̥t 20.3-4: atut tan tṛṣṇa riṅ jīva, savetniṅ lāra patya ya.

            Pādānuṣṭubh

            sakvehniṅ pada yan pathya, kālapa (863)laghuṅ akṣara, (864)pāda (865)kapiṅrvaB1:17r kapiṅpat, (866)pādānuṣṭup lvirniṅ (867)laku. [12] 13

            Śāpantika:  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓  /  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (868)āpan (869)ya tika (870)linәvih, (871)jñānāhayu (872)lavan ulah, (873)pūjā (874)satata tan alum, (875)śāpantika lagi-lagin. [13] 14
            Parallels
              śāpantika
            • Cf. Vr̥t 32.4 : śāpantikāliṅi mulat. However, the meter pattern of śāpantika in CK and Vr̥t is slightly different. In CK, śāpantika is presented as ––⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏑⏓, while in Vr̥t it is presented as ––⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑⏓.

            Vitana:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            lvirnikanaṅ (876)hayu (877)lagi, (878)yeki (879)dәlә̄n (880)tuladana, (881)śobha (882)vənaṅ saparana, divyaB2:11v (883)kadi pva vitana. [14] 15
            Parallels
              vitana
            • Cf. Vr̥t 33.4 : pakṣi vitāna sukādyus. In Vr̥t, the name of this meter is vitāna. The metric pattern is also slightly different in both CK and Vr̥t. In CK, vitana is presented as –⏑⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑⏓, while in Vr̥t vitāna has patterns as –⏑⏑|–⏑⏑|–⏓.

            Māṇavakakrīḍita:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            yapvan (884)ulah (885)lāgi tivas, hayva (886)ginәṅ bvat (887)hantukan, (888)doṣanikāmrih (889)kasulam, (890)māṇavakakrīḍita ya. [15] 16
            Parallels
              māṇavakakrīḍita
            • Cf. Vr̥t 31.3-4 : tusnya kinəmbəṅ madaləm, māṇavakākrīḍitaka.

            Vidyutmālā:  –  –  –  |  –  –  –  |  –  ⏓ 

            (891)ayva ṅvaṅ tan pamrih yatna, akveh lvirniṅ maṅde duhkha, (892)yāvat kevat śabdanteṅ len, (893)tāvat (894)mr̥tyū (895)vidyutmālā. [16] 17
            Parallels
              vidyutmālā
            • Cf. Vr̥t 34.4 : kumlab himpər vidyutmālā.

            Bhramaravilambita:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (896)apan ika saṅ vihikan, tan alupa riṅ pitutur, naga ta (897)taman gigirәn, bhramaravilambita ya. [18] 18
            Parallels
              bhramaravilambita
            • Cf. Vr̥t 35.3-4 : kusuma kataṅga sumār, bhramaravilambita ya.

            Bhujagaśiśukr̥ta:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏓ 

            (898)saphalakəna huripniṅvaṅ, (899)magavaya hayu sambega, ya taṅ usir (900)anurāgeṅ (901)rat, bhujagaśiśukr̥tāgurva. [21] 19
            Parallels
              bhujagaśiśukr̥ta
            • Cf. Vr̥t 36.3-4 : kanigara vuṅu lentañjuṅ, bhujagaśiśusr̥tā puṣpa. On the meters’ list of CK, the name of this meter is bhujaṅgasukr̥ta.

            Ayamukha:  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            hayva (902)vākparuṣa capala, yekaṅ abhyasa kaviratin, byakta moha puharanika, (903)doparanyanaṅ ayamukha. [22] 20
            Parallels
              ayamukha
            • Cf. Vr̥t 37.4 : yan tinon kadi halamukī.

            Turidagati:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            ya tikana vastuniṅ (904)avərə̄, ikaṅ (905)avamāna (906)puja (907)jəvah, (908)gərəmə təbəṅ (909)manmu (910)sukha, turidagatinya varəg (912)upet. [23] (911) 21
            Parallels
              turidagati
            • Cf. Vr̥t 40.4 : hananasibū tvaritagati. All CK evidences present clearly turidagati as the name for the 10-syllable meter (paṅkti) with the pattern |⏑–⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏓. Turidagati is most likely the indigenous name of the Sanskrit meter tvaritagati, which may be due to a misreading of the name, which also occurred with other meter names (cf. ayamukha instead of halamukhī). It is unclear whether this misreading occurred in the early adoption of the Sanskrit prosody to Javanese tradition or rather in the middle of a later transmission process. In Kalangwan (1974), Zoetmulder (1974: 113, 465) put turidagati as the name for the 22-syllable meter (ākr̥ti) which has the pattern ⏑⏑⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑–⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏑ –|⏑–⏑|⏓. However, it is still unclear from which source Zoetmulder took turidagati as the name for the first meter of ākr̥ti category. In fact, he himself still doubted his own decision regarding the name. Although it is still uncertain, a number of editions, e.g. Śivarātrikalpa (Teeuw, 1969), Kuñjarakarṇa Dharmakathana (Teeuw, 1981) and Arjunavivāha (Wiryamartana, 1990; Robson, 2008) describe the ākr̥ti meter with that pattern as turidagati. Therefore, the mention of turidagati in the whole CK evidences clarifies that turidagati could be another name for tvaritagati which is included in the paṅkti category, not ākr̥ti. The other problem then raises with regard to the name of the metre from the latest category, which should be discussed.

            Ambək śuddha:  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            sakvehniṅB2:12r (913)sukhaduhkha tan madoh, petən keriṅ avak (914)lavan manah, (915)nāhan (916)hetuni saṅ mahāmuni, ambək śuddha (917)pineti saṅ (918)mahan. [24] 22
            Parallels
              ambək śuddha
            • Cf. Vr̥t 41.4 : byaktaṅ śuddhavirāt pilih sisik

            Rukmavatī:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (919)deyanikā saṅ (920)sañjñana (921)buddhi, (922)saṅsara mahyun (923)riṅ sukha vāhya, mamrih (924)amūjā (925)sādhaka (926)riṅ hyaṅ, (927)rukmavatī (928)sādhyanya (929)sadāśrī. [26] 23
            Parallels
              rukmavatī
            • Cf. Vr̥t 42.4 : rukmavatī lvirniṅ raṇu denya. In the list of meters in CK, sadhanaśrī is its proper name, not rukmavatī.

            Pavana:  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏓ 

            (930)āpan saṅ sukha (931)tuməmuṅ prihnya, vvaṅ (932)vīdagdha ya (933)rasikā (934)ṅūni, (935)bhaktī hyaṅ kr̥tayaśa tan (936)seṅ vvaṅ, (937)gəṅniṅ (938)puṇya pavana (939)yānuntun. [27] 24
            Parallels
              pavana
            • Cf. Vr̥t 43.4 : śabdanyākr̥panavaṅiṅ megha. In the list of meters in CK, particularly in ms. J2 given that the other textual evidences are omitted, anuntun is its proper name, not pavana. However, it may be appropriate to take pavana to be a metathesis of paṇava.

            Jayendrabajra:  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            lvirniṅ (940)dadi (941)vvīt (942)ikanā (943)jatinya, maṅgəh (944)gavenyan paripūrṇa janma, hetunya mamrih (945)magave (946)parārtha, (947)rapvan (948)təmuṅ (949)vīrya (950)jayendrabajra. [28] 25
            Parallels
              jayendrabajra
            • Cf. Vr̥t 44.4 : svecānucuk padma kadīndrabajra.

            Upendrabajra:  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            ikaṅ (951)kavīryan (952)kalavan (953)sukhāgə̄ṅ, kapaṇḍitan dibya (954)ləvih rikiṅ rat, asiṅ sakojarnira tan kapāpa, (955)upendrabajropama taṅ (956)sulābha. [29] 26
            Parallels
              upendrabajra
            • Cf. Vr̥t 45.4 : tvasasmu sinyuh riṅ upendrabajra.

            Upasthita:  ⏓  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (957)svajātiniṅ rat maharəp kavīryan, (958)paḍāṅajap (959)bhyūdaya len (960)sukhāgəṅ, manah (961)jugāhyun (962)tama tan (963)paratra, (964)upasthitādoh (965)ri (966)sudharma saṅ hyaṅ. [30] 27
            Parallels
              upasthita
            • Cf. Vr̥t 46.4 : tenṅgal kitopasthita}he prənahku. In CK, upasthita has the same pattern with upendrabajra or upendravajrā, which may be stated that upasthita is another indigenous name of upendravajrā (at least in the CK). However, upasthita mentioned in Vr̥t deals with different rule of pattern than what is described in CK. The first and the third verse-line accomplish the pattern ⏑–⏑|––⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏓ belonging to upendrabajrā, while the second and the fourth has the pattern of jayendrabajra or indravajrā (––⏑|––⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏓). That is clear that upasthita has the same pattern rule as the upajāti meter from Sanskrit tradition, which combines upendravajrā and indravajrā meters. Therefore, it seems to be more reasonable to take upasthita as the indigenous name of upajāti, although the CK does not provide jayendrabajra’s pattern in upasthita.

            Dodhaka:  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (967)jātinikaṅ vvaṅ agəṅ (968)mada moha, kevala (969)buddhi taman vruh i (970)sornya, tan (971)sakayāsiga caṅkak-acaṅkak, (972)dodhaka (973)duhkha (974)magəṅ (975)tinəmunya. [31] 28

              dodhaka
            • Cf. Vr̥t 48 : śīghra ḍaṭəṅ kadi dodakavr̥tta.

            nā lvirniṅ vvaṅ (976)hīnayonī (977)haneṅ rat, (978)bheda mvaṅ saṅ (979)puṇya (980)mvaṅ (981)devayoni, (982)vīryā māsan (983)rūpavān lūd paneṣṭin, siṅ (985)solahnyan (986)sālisir tan pavarṇa. [32] (984) 29
            Parallels
              salisir
            • Cf. Vr̥t 49.4 : sugyan śokāśā linipteṅ laronəṅ.

            Vimala:  –  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (987)dūra pvekaṅ (988)mada moha ṅ (989)apə̄pa, maṅkin humvat (990)kasujanmannirāvan, kendran (991)ta kweh kalivat (992)yan kabhukti, (993)svecchā riṅ rāt (994)sthira tovin vimāla. [33] 30

            yogya ṅvaṅ (995)mabhyasa (996)sukha viratin, (997)atyantevəh ri (998)vənaṅa kuśala, śabdantārum kusuma paḍanika, (1000)devāṅrəṅva bhramaravilasita. [34] (999) 31

            mas maṇik juga viśeṣa (1001)rikiṅ rat, (1002)ndan (1003)ləvih (1004)təmən (1005)ikaṅ (1006)kasuśīlan, (1007)buddhi paṇḍita (1008)lavan hupaśānta, (1009)svāgateṅ para taṅan (1010)matalaṅkup. [35] 32

            Rathoddhatā:  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            saṅ narendra sira (1011)mībək iṅ jagat, tar (1012)vənaṅ (1013)haṅupakāra saṅ viku, byaktaniṅ (1014)kaviratin (1015)maharddhika, (1016)yāmr̥tāsuṅa (1017)vənaṅ (1018)rathoddhatā. [36] 33

            yeka mārganiṅ (1020)anəmvakən (1021)hayu, saṅ (1022)vənaṅ makadulur (1023)hajəṅnira, (1024)nīti nāga ta (1025)sirān tameṅ gita, (1026)srūni cihnani manah kabhikṣukan. [38] 35

              bhikṣuka
            • Based on its pattern, bhikṣuka is clearly the other name of rathoddhatā.

            Drutavilambita:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            paṅan (1027)inum si (1028)turū sukhaniṅ dadi, (1029)viṣaya rāga tumut ya (1030)lavan tuha, si tuha yeka (1031)tinūt tikanaṅ pati, (1032)drutavilambita janma punah-punah. [39] 36
            Parallels

            Vaṁśastha:  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (1033)nahan tinon saṅ (1034)viku (1035)niścayeṅ pati, dumeh (1036)sirāmrih (1037)maṅusī guhā gunuṅ, avak (1038)pinucchāpan avas (1039)hilaṅnika, (1040)kadi (1041)pva (1042)vaṅśastha (1043)sirāmuḍhāṅhina (1044)hina. 37

            Toṭaka:  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (1045)manaḍah ta gaṅan (1046)hatatāmirasa, (1047)virasa ndan (1048)aveh (1049)sukhacitta rasa, rasaniṅ (1050)mahurip ya katon (1051)rinasan, (1052)rasamātra (1053)ya toṭaka (1054)tulya kilat. 38

            • Cf. Vr̥t 58.4 : kuṅikāvətu toṭakagītarasa. The meter vīralalita in the list of CK have not been ilustrated yet. Or, it may be the other name of toṭaka?

            tuhu (1058)mata ya sukhenak (1059)bhoganiṅ (1060)rat, (1061)ri tutuk ika tan (1062)aṅgəh tuṣṭa (1063)riṅ heṅ, viṣaya (1064)si tama (1065)humvat rāga (1066)rāga (1067)vr̥ddhi, riṅ avasana katr̥ṣṇan (1068)śrīpuṭāśā. [43] 40

            Bhujaṅgaprayatna:  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            pəjah (1079)pveka (1080)saṅ vus (1081)lanā puṇya (1082)riṅ rat, umantuk sireṅ (1083)svargalokaB2:14r hyaṅ indra, yayan (1084)bhāvacakra (1085)ndan olih (1086)salambvan, (1087)ləhəṅ (1088)saṅka ri (1089)crol (1090)bhujaṅgaprayatna. [48] 42

            Bhramitākṣara:  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            aparan kunaṅ (1091)phalanikaṅ kuhaka, (1092)inalәm (1093)tahāsukha madoh (1094)mata ya, śata (1095)janma-janma saparanya cәmәr, (1096)bhramitākṣaranya saparanya tivas. [49] 43

            Vaiśvadevī:  –  –  –  –  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            hetunyan prihәn taṅ (1097)ulah (1098)sādhubuddhi, (1099)āpan vyartha (1100)tāpa (1101)suśīla (1102)vruheriṅ, (1103)siṅ ṅvaṅ (1104)sādhv (1105)atambәha riṅ (1106)rāmareṇa, (1107)maṅkā (1108)strī (1109)ya satya ya (1110)taṅ (1111)vaiśvadevī. (1112)[50] 44
            Parallels
              vaiśvadevī
            • Cf. Vr̥t 63.4 : śobhāṅ māhantən vaiśvadevy aṅgaluntaṅ.

            Turagagati:  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ 

            (1113)dvaniṅ vvaṅ ahurip (1114)śaraṇagata, (1115)mareṅ agati (1116)sarva (1117)kasih arәp, (1118)yapvan vәnaṅa (1119)sāma (1120)tapasana, lәhәṅ (1121)matәmahan (1122)turagagati. [85], 45

            Navamālinī:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            (1123)syapa sira tan (1124)paṅastava (1125)suśīla, (1126)matuha rare paḍa vruh (1127)ika tan sor, (1128)kunaṅ (1129)ivәh iṅ (1130)vәnaṅ (1131)praṇata (1132)bhakti, (1133)kadi navamālinī (1134)jugani sojar. [51] 46
            Parallels
              navamālinī
            • Cf. Vr̥t 64.4 : abhinavamālinī tilatilamnya.

            Kusumapadānta:  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏓ 

            mataṅ ikaB1:22rB2:14v saṅ (1135)vruh gumagap (1136)ikaṅ (1137)me-, (1138)-vәh anumaneṅ rat (1139)ṅuni-ṅuniṅāpuṅ-, (1140)-guṅ (1141)apan (1142)ikaṅ (1143)vruh (1144)mavara-varah (1145)doh, (1146)bhaya tan (1147)asiṅ vvaṅ (1148)kusumapadānta. [52] 47
            Parallels
              kusumapadānta
            • Based on its pattern, kusumapadānta is clearly the other name of kusumavicitra in stanza 41.

            Praharṣiṇī:  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏑  –  ⏓

            ya hetu saṅ vruha kulamitra gәṅ (1162)taha, (1163)uṣādha tapva (1164)hinanakәn (1165)pasaṅgrahan, (1166)ivәhnikiṅ giṇa (1167)mahurip (1168)sadāsukha, (1169)nahan katon (1170)surucira (1171)snāha (1172)sādhana.B1:22v (1173)[54], 49

            syapaB1:23v tan (1246)atakuta mulati munivara, (1247)tәkap i samahita ya kadi gunuṅ (1248)apuy, (1249)brata japa (1250)ginәlarira (1251)mamәnuhi (1252)rat,B2:15r kalana (1253)kәḍik ika (1254)maṇiguṇanikara. [59] 55
            Parallels
              maṇiguṇanikara
            • Cf. Vr̥t 77.4 : suka maṇi guṇanikaranika yanimaləm. It should be noted that maṇiguṇanikara described in CK has 14 syllables, while those which is provided in Vr̥t has 15 syllables. In Sanskrit, those 15 syllables maṇiguṇanikara are called śaśikalā.

            (1278)vvaṅ (1279)nīca mitra sujana (1280)sakarәṅ (1281)buddhinyātut, tan (1282)maṅga yan (1283)paḍa sujana (1284)paḍa crol (1285)satyātūt, (1286)sojarny atūt (1287)silihiraṅ (1288)aṅasihan yāpāṅguṣṭha, (1289)kumbaṅ lavan (1290)kuvalayakusuma (1291)lvirnyan meriṅ. [63] 58
            Parallels
              kuvalayakusuma
            • Cf. Vr̥t 72.4 : madhyanyāñjrah kuvalayakusumanya mrikmar. The meter kuvalayakusuma in the Vr̥t has the 14 syllables whose the short-long patterns are identical with madhyakṣāmā in Sanskrit while the CK has the 15 syllables of kuvalayakusuma.

[46] 64
            Parallels
              citralekha
            • Cf. Vr̥t 87.4 : lāvan tekā lothiniliṅiliṅan citralekanta lambaṅ. All corpus of CK provide citralekha in the illustration as a meter having 17 syllables whose the pattern is identical as mandākrānta. However, I have to take a position to emend the citralekha as a distinctive meter compared to mandākrānta. The problem could be the missing of a long syllable at the beginning of each line.

            Mandākrāntā:  –  –  –  –  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  –  ⏑  –  ⏓

              śārdūlavikrīḍita

            (1536)dūra (1537)pvaṅ vvaṅ (1538)vәnaṅ (1539)maṅkana tumulada (1540)saṅ (1541)bhāgyā kr̥tavara, (1542)āpan makral matiṅgar kadi vatu lumutәn (1543)byaktan (1544)kasalәyә̄, (1545)nyātaṅ (1546)vāhya (1547)trikāyān (1548)kavәnaṅa (1549)sakarәṅ (1550)gambhīra (1551)dahatәn, śabdolah (1553)vehi (1554)somyālәmәs (1555)asәmu guyu (1556)lvirniṅ (1557)suvadana · || 73 || [77],(1552)

            Kakavin

            (1926)kṣamakәna (1927)matike vuvusniṅ hulun (1928)ndah kamuṅ hyaṅ ya (1929)sakveh ta (1930)sūkṣmāganal muṅgu (1931)riṅ, (1932)deśa deśāntare sor (1933)iṅ (1934)ūrdhah lavan (1935)madya (1936)deśātmakāniṅ jagat lyab (1937)sakālanta (1938)devāṣṭamūrti (1939)pratiṣṭhanta (1940)sākṣāt (1941)rәṅə̄ ta (1942)kṣamāniṅ hulun (1943)svastha (1944)dīrghāyuṣāmaṅguh (1945)enak (1946)sadāyovanā, 1

            ṅuniṅuni ta (1947)mahāmunī saṅ (1948)vәnaṅ (1949)meh kaniśśreyaśān iṅ (1950)liṅiṅ (1951)saṅ kavī paṇḍita (1952)mvaṅ (1953)ta saṅ vagmi riṅ (1954)tattvavīt iṅ vatәk (1955)vāla (1956)vidyā laB1:32rvan saṅ (1957)mahāsajjanārәmba (1958)riṅ (1959)dharma (1960)kāryenak ambәk (1961)yaśa (1962)sih lavan (1963)dāna (1964)puṇya praṇamyaṅku (1965)tonәn (1966)rәṅə̄ (1967)ta stutiṅkun vruhante (1968)katuṣṭiṅku (1969)bhaktyādalәm,

            (1970)tәka ri (1971)pusupusuhku sumsum (1972)hutәk (1973)tvas dagiṅ rahku (1974)sakvehny (1975)avakniṅ (1976)ṅhulun bhakti (1977)riṅ (1978)vāhyavāhyaṅ kulәm (1979)sārisāri (1980)praṇātā (1981)satāta (1982)pradiptojvalāmbәkku tan (1983)pāntarāṅūsapiṅ (1984)jə̄ṅ (1985)mañiptālanā (1986)tvaṅ magәṅ (1987)prastavanyan (1988)vәnaṅ (1989)marṇanā (1990)jñāna saṅ (1991)paṇḍitāṅusvakәn (1992)kottaman (1993)saṅ (1994)tapaḥsiddha (1995)yogīśvarātūt tutur hetuka, (1997)vuṅuvuṅu (1998)śatapattra tuñjuṅ (1999)hijo (2000)dhūpa (2001)dīpārcanā (2002)śaṅkha (2003)ghaṇṭā (2004)satātaṅ (2005)sәkar (2006)rәb rinok (2007)riṅ (2008)jәnuṅ (2009)vr̥tti (2010)sāteja nāhan ta (2011)simpәnnikiṅ (2012)kavya (2013)kābhyāsa (2014)saṅ hyaṅ (2015)kachandan ya (2016)vargāsәkar tanJ3:13v (2017)kәnālum (2018)pamūjāṅku (2019)muṅgv iṅ (2020)rikaṅ (2021)daṇḍakā (2022)chanda (2023)nāhan (2024)ta vr̥ṣṭi (2025)prayatna (2026)stutīniṅ (2027)hulun (2028)riṅ vatәk (2029)devatā · [104],(1996)

            (2031)atha (2032)sampun (2033)ikaṅ guru (2034)lāghu lavan (2035)gaṇa (2036)mātra (2037)yatinya (2038)padanya (2039)suchanda (2040)mavr̥tta (2041)matūt (2042)marikān(2043)pinarākr̥ta denika saṅ kavi (2044)dāśanamāṅanumāna ri saṅ (2045)maharәp vruha riṅ (2046)paribhāṣa (2047)kavīśvara kavya (2048)ṅaran kiraṇa pva ya (2049)donanikānaṅ (2050)atirvana yan (2051)paṅәne (2052)matikā (2053)pinarah (2054)tәkәnanta (2055)mareṅ kavi (2056)dibya nihan ya vaneh kunәṅ (2057)utpәnaniṅ hulun (2058)akṣamakәn ta (2059)tәmәn (2060)matikeṅ (2061)ayu lon (2062)sahananta (2063)mahājana siṅ (2064)sira mahyuna (2065)tāsisinahv (2066)aṅusir (2067)tikanaṅ (2068)rasa (2069)gīta (2070)kavyanira (2071)saṅ (2072)rahatiṅ (2073)parapet (2074)rusit iṅ (2075)paribhāṣa (2076)maran (2077)saphalātiśayanta katon (2078)satirun (2079)sigәgәn ta (2080)rәṅə̄n (2081)sapujin (2082)matikin (2083)prihәniṅ (2084)magave (2085)yaśa (2086)devata yoni ṅaranya (2087)vәnaṅ (2088)kavinәn (2089)tuhu (2090)buddhi (2091)mahan kadi (2092)ḍaṇḍaka (2093)nāma (2094)malāhati (2095)yojvala (2096)lə̄ṅnya madәg · \\\par,(2030) 2

            (2097)pәṅpәṅ teku (2098)hurip (2099)tatāmriha (2100)tapāṅuratana (2101)kavikun (2102)palar (2103)biṣa, (2104)ayvāṅgə̄ṅ yaśa (2105)vīrya (2106)śāstra (2107)kavilәt ṅvaṅ ika (2108)kasamayā (2109)punarbhava, tonton (2110)duhkhanikiṅ (2111)dadi vvaṅ adulur (2112)prihati (2113)kasakitan mamet (2114)sukha, (2115)aṅriṅkәl (2116)viṣayanya pan (2117)pinakavāśanika (2118)vulat (2119)ananta tan tirun. 3

            (2120)posikniṅ (2121)prih (2122)anūtakәn brata (2123)samādhi (2124)karaṇani (2125)ḍatәṅ(2126)nikaṅ (2127)sukha, tan (2128)saṅkeṅ (2129)kaluṣā (2130)lәmәh (2131)palәpalәh (2132)karukaru (2133)kuhakāptiniṅ (2134)turu, yadyan papraṅ (2135)avikva tovi (2136)madagaṅ (2137)tan upirupir (2138)ikan (2139)tәkeṅ (2140)tәkan, (2141)pūjā (2142)mvaṅ (2143)vyavasāya (2144)taṅhi (2145)pinakāśrayanira ri katәmvaniṅ (2146)hayu. 4

            syapa (2147)sira mahyun (2148)vihikana mojar, (2149)tamakәna taṅ (2150)chanda (2151)ginava denya, (2152)huvus (2153)apagәh denta tumamakәnya, niyata (2154)biṣantāṅucapucap enak. 5

            colophon

            (2155)iti (2156)vr̥tta (2157)samāpta · \

            om. B1 B2
            This line is absent in the Balinese mss. It is hard to determine if the absence there is due to omission in the course of transmission, or vice versa, where an interpolation has taken place in the Javanese transmission (for which only J2 is available here).            sujanātiharṣa B1 B2
            sujanādi harṣa J2            irikaṅ J2
            ruməṅə̄ B1ruməṅə B2
            Since harṣa ruməṅə̄ is a rather frequently occurring phrase in OJ literature, I consider it likely that the B recension replaced an authorial reading irikaṅ preserved in J2.            kavruhi B1
            kavruhī J2vruhi B2            laghu lavan tekā em.

            Interestingly, that the word apaṇa in this text seems to be a metanalysis of apāna "one of five vital airs (pañcabāyu)". Or, it could be an adopted Sanskrit word from āpaṇa "market" as ms. B2 mentionned, but this word is not recorded yet on OJED and not acceptable in metri causa.            ṇa gә̄ṅ B1

            This emendation is based on two reasons: (1) the words in this line are correlationg with any moving object (ghana, vāhana) and its characteristic (vāni); and (2) the word vāhinī is mentionned just in the next stanza.            nītinitya norm.

            It is interesting that the copyist of ms. B1 unintentionally neglects the next stanza by the phrase na lit ika (saut du même au même) which is also written in the end of the next stanza.            vanā B2

            Both puṣya and puṣpa are acceptable for the reading. It seems that the Balinese scribes considered that the word puṣpa is missing on the list, so that the reason they added this word.            poṣaka em.

            bhaviṣya B1 B2
            According to the OJED, the Sanskrit word īrṣyā has many metanalysis in Old-Javanese such as īrṣya, ariṣya, hīrṣya, irisya. That is why the word hiriṣya in this reading might be acceptable.            harṣaṇa em.

            Cf. Vr̥t 32.4 : śāpantikāliṅi mulat. However, the meter pattern of śāpantika in CK and Vr̥t is slightly different. In CK, śāpantika is presented as ––⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏑⏓, while in Vr̥t it is presented as ––⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑⏓.            hayu J1 J2 B2

            tuladhana J1 J2            śobha B1 B2
            soṅa J1 J2            vənaṅ norm.
            vnaṅ J1 J2 B1            kadi pva J1 B1 B2
            khadī pya J2            vitana
            Cf. Vr̥t 33.4 : pakṣi vitāna sukādyus. In Vr̥t, the name of this meter is vitāna. The metric pattern is also slightly different in both CK and Vr̥t. In CK, vitana is presented as –⏑⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑⏓, while in Vr̥t vitāna has patterns as –⏑⏑|–⏑⏑|–⏓.            ulah J1 B1 B2

            Cf. Vr̥t 37.4 : yan tinon kadi halamukī.            avərə̄ B1
            avərə J2 B2            avamāna B2
            avamana B1āvamāṇa J2            puja J2
            puji B1 B2            jəvah B1 B2
            jīva J2            gərəmə təbəṅ J2
            gərəmətən hiṅ B1gərəmətən ṅhiṅ B2            manmu norm.
            manmu J2 B1            sukha norm.
            suka B1śuka J2            upet B2
            upīt J2upə̄t B1            turidagati
            Cf. Vr̥t 40.4 : hananasibū tvaritagati. All CK evidences present clearly turidagati as the name for the 10-syllable meter (paṅkti) with the pattern |⏑–⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏓. Turidagati is most likely the indigenous name of the Sanskrit meter tvaritagati, which may be due to a misreading of the name, which also occurred with other meter names (cf. ayamukha instead of halamukhī). It is unclear whether this misreading occurred in the early adoption of the Sanskrit prosody to Javanese tradition or rather in the middle of a later transmission process. In Kalangwan (1974), Zoetmulder (1974: 113, 465) put turidagati as the name for the 22-syllable meter (ākr̥ti) which has the pattern ⏑⏑⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏑⏑|⏑–⏑|⏑⏑⏑|⏑ –|⏑–⏑|⏓. However, it is still unclear from which source Zoetmulder took turidagati as the name for the first meter of ākr̥ti category. In fact, he himself still doubted his own decision regarding the name. Although it is still uncertain, a number of editions, e.g. Śivarātrikalpa (Teeuw, 1969), Kuñjarakarṇa Dharmakathana (Teeuw, 1981) and Arjunavivāha (Wiryamartana, 1990; Robson, 2008) describe the ākr̥ti meter with that pattern as turidagati. Therefore, the mention of turidagati in the whole CK evidences clarifies that turidagati could be another name for tvaritagati which is included in the paṅkti category, not ākr̥ti. The other problem then raises with regard to the name of the metre from the latest category, which should be discussed.            sukhaduhkha norm.
            sukaduhka B1 B2śukaduhka J2            lavan manah J2

            suka gəṅ J2sukāgəṅ B1 B2            jugāhyun B1 B2
            juga hyun J2            tama J2
            tamā B1 B2            paratra J2
            parārtha B1parārta B2            upasthitādoh norm.
            upasvikādoh J2upasṭitādoh B1umasvitādoh B2            ri J2 B1
            riṅ B2            sudharma B2
            sadharma J2suḍarma B1            upasthita
            Cf. Vr̥t 46.4 : tenṅgal kitopasthita}he prənahku. In CK, upasthita has the same pattern with upendrabajra or upendravajrā, which may be stated that upasthita is another indigenous name of upendravajrā (at least in the CK). However, upasthita mentioned in Vr̥t deals with different rule of pattern than what is described in CK. The first and the third verse-line accomplish the pattern ⏑–⏑|––⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏓ belonging to upendrabajrā, while the second and the fourth has the pattern of jayendrabajra or indravajrā (––⏑|––⏑|⏑–⏑|–⏓). That is clear that upasthita has the same pattern rule as the upajāti meter from Sanskrit tradition, which combines upendravajrā and indravajrā meters. Therefore, it seems to be more reasonable to take upasthita as the indigenous name of upajāti, although the CK does not provide jayendrabajra’s pattern in upasthita.            jātinikaṅ J2

            citralitī J2citraliti J3citralika B1citralike B1            sisinya B1 B2
            śīṣīnya J2śiṣinya J3            citralekha
            Cf. Vr̥t 87.4 : lāvan tekā lothiniliṅiliṅan citralekanta lambaṅ. All corpus of CK provide citralekha in the illustration as a meter having 17 syllables whose the pattern is identical as mandākrānta. However, I have to take a position to emend the citralekha as a distinctive meter compared to mandākrānta. The problem could be the missing of a long syllable at the beginning of each line.            yāvat J2

            Le B1 se termine dans cette partie.            tәlulikur […] nәmlikur.
            pādānuṣṭup irrégulière            duvәg […]
            Le J1 a réécrit la strophe || 61 || comme suit: nda nahan vignaniṅ agavai tapa brata laṇā marupuhi ri hati, ya kadhә̄hanira ya maṅaḍī laṇā ri vṅi yā tika kinatuturan, niyāta manahira magavaiy tahan tulakniṅ japa samaḍi laṇa, / apan ākara hima maśa kīta saṅ munivarā bhujaga vilaśiha ·; mais je ne l’ai pas inclus dans l’édition car les trois autres manuscrits ne l’ont pas réécrit.            rāgantāgә̄ṅ […] anakәbini
            Cette strophe entière est omise dans le #msba.            śivapattra…hana ta
            An omission intervenes in B1            aparājita…avitana
            An omission intervenes in B1 B2             […] .

            Unmetrical. The pattern of the lines is  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  –  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  –  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏓ .             […] ,
            Unmetrical. The pattern of the lines is  –  ⏑  ⏑  |  –  ⏑  ⏑  |  –  ⏑  (  ⏓  )  |  –  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  –  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  ⏑  –  ⏑  |  –  ⏑  ⏓ .             […] [104],
            Unmetrical. The pattern of the lines is  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ‖  –  ⏑  –  ‖ .            atha […] \\\par,
            Unmetrical. The pattern of the lines is  ‖  ⏑  ⏑  –  ‖ .

            Apparatus

            ^31. mvaṅ laku śloka nihan len] J2, om. B1 B2 • This line is absent in the Balinese mss. It is hard to determine if the absence there is due to omission in the course of transmission, or vice versa, where an interpolation has taken place in the Javanese transmission (for which only J2 is available here).
            ^32. sujanātiharṣa] B1 B2, sujanādi harṣa J2
            ^33. irikaṅ] J2, ruməṅə̄ B1, ruməṅə B2 • Since harṣa ruməṅə̄ is a rather frequently occurring phrase in OJ literature, I consider it likely that the B recension replaced an authorial reading irikaṅ preserved in J2.

            ^221. ṅ apaṇa] B1, hapaṇa J2, ṅāpaṇa B2 • Interestingly, that the word apaṇa in this text seems to be a metanalysis of apāna "one of five vital airs (pañcabāyu)". Or, it could be an adopted Sanskrit word from āpaṇa "market" as ms. B2 mentionned, but this word is not recorded yet on OJED and not acceptable in metri causa.

            ^403. hiriṣya] J1 J2 J2, bhaviṣya B1 B2 • According to the OJED, the Sanskrit word īrṣyā has many metanalysis in Old-Javanese such as īrṣya, ariṣya, hīrṣya, irisya. That is why the word hiriṣya in this reading might be acceptable.

            ^1459. kadali […] [71],] Unmetrical. The pattern of the lines is  ⏑  ⏑  ⏑  |  ⏑  ⏑  –  |  –  –  –  |  –  ⏑  –  |  ⏑  ⏑  –  |  ⏑  ⏓ .

            ^1666. bratāśvalalita] B1, bratāṅ śvalalita J1, brataśyalalita J2, brataśvalalita J3
            ^1667. duvәg […] ] Le J1 a réécrit la strophe || 61 || comme suit: nda nahan vignaniṅ agavai tapa brata laṇā marupuhi ri hati, ya kadhә̄hanira ya maṅaḍī laṇā ri vṅi yā tika kinatuturan, niyāta manahira magavaiy tahan tulakniṅ japa samaḍi laṇa, / apan ākara hima maśa kīta saṅ munivarā bhujaga vilaśiha ·; mais je ne l’ai pas inclus dans l’édition car les trois autres manuscrits ne l’ont pas réécrit.
